EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Sunrise Power Company, LLC utilizes anhydrous ammonia in two identical 
selective catalytic reduction (SCR) processes for the two gas turbines at their 
power plant near Fellows, California.  Since each SCR process handles more 
than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has 
developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) program for 
the SCR processes.  

As part of the PSM program, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has completed 
process hazard analyses, developed written operating procedures, trained 
employees on the SCR processes, conducted a pre-startup safety review, and 
developed a mechanical integrity program for the ammonia equipment.  In 
addition to plant personnel monitoring the operation of the SCR processes on a 
daily basis, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has implemented a preventative 
maintenance program to ensure that the SCR processes are maintained in good 
operating condition.  Plant personnel monitor the operation of the SCR processes 
on a daily basis.  Properly maintained equipment reduces the risk of an 
accidental release.

Additionally, Sunrise Power Company, LLC emphasizes safe and 
environmentally sound operating practices and procedures through their 
employee training programs.  In addition to job specific and process specific 
training, operators and maintenance personnel receive training in fire prevention, 
fire control, accident prevention, safety, and first aid.  

While it is Sunrise Power Company, LLC's objective to be a responsible citizen of 
the community in all of its business activities, the limited staff at the power plant 
precludes emergency response operations.  As such, an emergency action plan 
has been prepared for the Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility and a chain of 
command to respond to emergencies has been established.

ailed Compliance Audit 
Checklist which is used to evaluate compliance with the PSM and RMP 
regulations.  At least every three years, Sunrise Power Company, LLC will audit 
these programs and any findings of noncompliance will be documented and

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

The Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility is located on approximately 16 acres 
in Section 23, T31S/R22E, MDB&M in the sparsely populated Midway-Sunset oil 
field.  The plant is located approximately 3 miles northwest of the community of 
Fellows, 2.5 miles south of Derby Acres, and 1.3 miles west of Highway 33.  

The Sunrise Power Company, LLC power plant produced commercial power for 
the first time on June 26, 2001 configured as a 320 megawatt simple cycle 
peaker plant.  Two natural gas fired General Electric Frame 7FA turbines 
physically coupled to electric generators provided the power during the peak 
demand period of the California energy crisis in the summer of 2001.  

In December 2001, construction began on an expansion of the facility that would 
convert the simple cycle 320 megawatt peaker plant into a 585 megawatt 
combined cycle power plant.  The Phase II expansion included installation of 
two duct-fired heat recovery steam generators (HSRG) and a 265 megawatt 
steam generator.  To help control the nitrogen oxide emissions from the gas 
turbine, each HRSG is equipped with an anhydrous ammonia-based selective 
catalytic reduction (SCR) system.  

In the SCR process, anhydrous ammonia vapors from the storage tank are 
injected into the high temperature turbine exhaust ahead of the catalytic reactor.  
The high temperature of the exhaust causes the ammonia to dissociate and 
create a reducing atmosphere before the flue gas enters the catalytic reactor.  
This reducing atmosphere in the turbine flue gas helps convert nitrogen oxides to 
nitrogen and water as the

flue gas passes through the catalytic reactor.  The 
operation of the SCR system substantially lowers the emissions of nitrogen 
oxides from the gas turbine.

The SCR systems at the Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility are identical.  
Anhydrous ammonia is stored in two 5,300 gallon (water capacity) storage tanks.  
The maximum intended inventory of each anhydrous ammonia storage tank is 
physically limited to approximately 4,500 gallons through the installation of a 
overflow stand pipe inside each tank.  The overflow stand pipe is installed on the 
ammonia delivery vapor return line and limits the capacity of the tank to 
approximately 85 percent.  If the ammonia delivery truck operator fills the storage 
tank above 85 percent capacity, the excess ammonia is returned to the delivery 
truck through the vapor line.  Additionally, each tank is equipped with a level 
transmitter that will close emergency shutoff valves on the ammonia delivery 
lines if the tank level exceeds 85 percent.  Limiting the capacity of the anhydrous 
ammonia storage tank to 85 percent establishes a maximum storage capacity of 
approximately 22,664 pounds.

For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, 40 CFR Part 68 defines the 
toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).




Worst Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

Offsite consequence analyses are used as tools to assist in emergency response 
planning.  The RMP regulations require the owner or operator of a stationary 
source to analyze the offsite impacts due to an accidental release of a regulated 
substance.  The offsite consequence analysis for a Program 3 process must 
analyze the worst case release scenario and an alternative release scenario.  
Since Sunrise Power Company, LLC's SCR systems are considered Program 3 
processes, both release scenarios were evaluated in the offsite consequence 
analysis.

Five-Year Accident History

Sunrise Power Company, LLC began commercial operation of the power plant in 
June 2001 and will commission the ammonia based SCR process in the spring of 
2003.  The Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility has not had any accidental 
releases that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on 
site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property 
damage, or environmental damage.

Emergency Response Program

Sunrise Power Company, LLC has established an emergency action plan and a 
chain of command to respond to emergencies and to notify emergency 
responders when there is a need for a response.  However, an emergency 
response program does not need to be developed for the facility since Sunrise 
Power Company, LLC employees will not respond to accidental releases of 
ammonia, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan, and 
appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.  

Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Through the accidental release prevention program, Sunrise Power Company, 
LLC regularly evaluates the need for any changes to improve safety.  Currently, 
Sunrise Power Company, LLC does not have any changes to the anhydrous 
ammonia-based SCR processes planned to improve safety.

population within an area potentially affected by the accidental release scenario.  
This area is defined as a circle with a radius equivalent to the distance the 
release would travel with concentrations at or above the toxic endpoint.  The 
circle also defines the area in which potential environmental receptors must be 
identified.

The worst case release is defined by the U.S. EPA as the total release of the 
contents of the single largest vessel or pipe within 10 minutes.  For liquefied 
gases stored under pressure, the entire contents of the vessel or pipe are 
assumed to be released as a vapor.  A total vapor release is highly unlikely.  
However, this standardized worst case scenario was developed for emergency 
response agencies to use for planning purposes.

In the selection of the worst case release scenario, the RMP regulations also 
require the analysis of an additional scenario if such a scenario would result in a 
greater distance to an endpoint beyond the facility boundary.  This additional 
scenario would be based on smaller quantities handled at higher process 
temperature or pressure and proximity to the boundary of the facility.  

An alternative release scenario is a release that is more likely to occur than the 
worst case release scenario.  For Sunrise Power Company, LLC, the alternative 
release scenario was selected based on the results of the Process Hazard 
Analysis (PHA) for the ammonia-based SCR process.  A credible release event 
with a high discharge rate would potentially have the greatest offsite impact from 
an alternate release.  A failure (or sudden uncoupling) of the ammonia delivery 
hose was identified in the PHA as having a low probability of occurrence but with 
a discharge rate high enough to cause an offsite impact, and therefore, was 
chosen as the alternative release scenario.

Sunrise Power Company, LLC has analyzed the offsite consequences of the 
worst case scenarios

for each of the SCR systems and alternative release 
scenarios.  For the worst case release scenario, the release of 22,664 pounds of 
ammonia was modeled over a 10 minute period.  The RMP*Comp model 
indicated the worst case plume from each SCR system would travel 1.90 miles at 
concentrations at or above the endpoint.  

Although the SCR systems are approximately 100 feet apart, the worst case 
release scenario from the SCR systems could potentially affect different 
populations.  Using 1990 Census data from the Landview IIIr Environmental 
Software, the population potentially affected within the worst case release 
scenario circle from the Unit 1 SCR system is 40 persons.  Utilizing the same 
1990 Census data, the estimated population potentially affected by the worst 
case release from the Unit 2 SCR system is also 40 persons.  Based on these 
data, the same populations are affected from either worst case release scenario.  
Due to the rural location of this facility, the population potentially affected by 
these worst case releases may be substantially overstated by the 1990 Census 
data.  The public receptors may include a couple of residences.  There are no 
environmental receptors within the worst case release scenario circles.

In the alternative release scenario, a failure or sudden uncoupling of the delivery 
hose was modeled as a release of liquefied ammonia stored under pressure.  For 
a release of 554 lb/min (110 gpm) of anhydrous ammonia, the plume would travel 
0.2 mile at concentrations at or above the endpoint.  No residences are located 
within the 0.2 mile area around the Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility.  As 
such, there would be no population impacts from the alternative release scenario.  
There were also no environmental receptors within the alternative release 
scenario circle. 

The modeling performed as part of this offsite consequence analysis does not 
take into account the use of the remote operated shuto

ff valves that were 
installed at the ammonia tank.  These isolation valves take approximately 10 to 
15 seconds to fully close and could greatly reduce the impact of a hose failure 
release.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific 
Prevention Steps

A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release 
prevention program, is being implemented at Sunrise Power Company, LLC to 
address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program includes the 
following chemical-specific prevention steps:

	Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the 
hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in 
the process has been compiled.

	Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) have been completed and will be 
updated and revalidated at least every five years.

	Written operating procedures have been developed and will be reviewed 
at least annually.

	Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, 
opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the 
facility have been developed and implemented.

	Each employee involved in operating the ammonia system has received 
initial training and refresher training at least every three years.

	Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and 
implemented.

	A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed and 
implemented to address all proposed changes to the ammonia system.

	Pre-startup safety reviews will be performed when a modification is made 
to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in 
the process safety information.

	Audits will be conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance 
with the RMP regulations.

	Incident investigation procedures have been established.

	A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee 
participation has been developed and implemented.
